meanings.definition: To release or secure the release of a prisoner by providing money or property as security.
meanings.sent1: The kind judge decided to bail out the young man who made a mistake.
meanings.sent2: The lawyer helped bail the accused person out of jail.
meanings.sent3: The police officer had to bail out the mischievous cat stuck in a tree.
meanings.sent4: She always bails her friends out of trouble when they need help.
meanings.sent5: The superhero swooped in to bail the city out of danger.

meanings.definition: A sum of money deposited as security to ensure the appearance of a defendant in court.
meanings.sent1: The defendant had to pay bail to be released before the trial.
meanings.sent2: The judge set a high bail amount for the accused person.
meanings.sent3: The bail for the court appearance was a hefty sum.
meanings.sent4: He couldn't afford the bail, so he stayed in jail.
meanings.sent5: The bail was returned after the court case was over.

meanings.definition: To scoop water out of a boat.
meanings.sent1: The sailor had to bail water out of the leaking boat.
meanings.sent2: They used a bucket to bail out the water from the small boat.
meanings.sent3: The children pretended to bail water out of their imaginary boat.
meanings.sent4: He had to bail out the boat quickly to prevent it from sinking.
meanings.sent5: The storm forced them to bail water out of the boat all night.
